instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL: What is SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL? SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL is the clock line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED. If this line’s resistance to ground is too low because of a defective component, battery will not be recognized with an X on the icon and PPBUS_G3H voltage will be lower than it is on a good system..
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA: What is SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA? SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA is the data line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED. If this line’s resistance to ground is too low because of a defective component, battery will not be recognized with an X on the icon and PPBUS_G3H voltage will be lower than it is on a good system..
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with strange <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hello Community!

I have a liquid damaged logicboard which does not see the battery. Corrosion was around the <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> area and the J6950 jack. 
Tested with known good battery.
[LIST]
[*]<RESISTOR>R5380</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5380</RESISTOR> both have 2k.
[*]<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL</SIGNAL>
[LIST]
[*]2,48V - 3,5V (2,48V is the baseline. Pulses are getting up to 3,5V)
[*]0.5440V diode-mode
[/LIST]
[*]<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA</SIGNAL>
[LIST]
[*]0-3,42V (looks like normal communication)
[*]0.5400V diode-mode
[/LIST]
[/LIST]
The SMC does not seem to short the SCL line to GND. It increases the voltage. Any ideas before I have to take a deeper look at the SMC?

Thanks for your help. Nice to be here! :D

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with strange <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Possibly corrosion under the SMC. I'd say inspect for signs of liquid near it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with strange <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with strange <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
No Title

[USER="1153"]JohnB8812[/USER] 
No corrosion at the back of the LB. SMC and surrounding looks fine.

@2informaticos
<RESISTOR>R6950</RESISTOR> is within the specs (9,88k)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with strange <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
John suggested corrosion under SMC, not on its opposite side.
So put a bit good flux and reflow to 180-200 degrees; this should burn all the crap.

Resistance to ground looks good on SCLD/SDA.
Change <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> first.
If no result, try other SMC.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with strange <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 40918"]John suggested corrosion under SMC, not on its opposite side.
So put a bit good flux and reflow to 180-200 degrees; this should burn all the crap.

Resistance to ground looks good on SCLD/SDA.
Change <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> first.
If no result, try other SMC.[/QUOTE]

Reflowing and changing the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> did not solve the problem. I will look for a donor SMC.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with strange <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Replacing the SMC did the job :D At a second Board with the same issue a reflow of the SMC was enought.

Thanks for your help!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with strange <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL</SIGNAL>
